subject: Re: [junit] regarding junit perf
msgSnippet: ... JUnitPerf requires that you know the performance criteria for a section of code under test.  This should be based on quantifiable performance requirements,
messageBody:
BalaSubramanian wrote:

> Hi
> I need your help very urgently .I am using JunitPerf
> I am running timedTest and loadTest .Let me have some queries
> 1) Timed Test
> ---------------
>
> How can i predict the MaxElapsedTime for a function
> If iam running on some unix flavors , i will run the test on server .
>
> If am running the same program on another terminal ,then the load
> will increase .At that time , the time taken for the function
> will increase , it will say "Test is failed bcoz it takes more
> time than maxElapsedTime ". Is there any way to calculate
> the MaxElapsedTime .
>

JUnitPerf requires that you know the performance criteria for a section
of code under test. This should be based on quantifiable performance
requirements, user tolerances, or an arbitrary measurable improvement
over the existing response times and throughput. If performance isn't
important for a certain section of code, then don't write a performance
test for it. If it is important, then you should have some expected
response time to use as a benchmark.


> Your Program :-
> ------------------
> Timer timer = new ConstantTimer(250);
> int maxUsers = 100;
> int iterations = 10;
> long maxElapsedTime = 12000;
>
> The overall test duration is not to exceed 12 seconds.
> How u are predicting this maxElapsedTime for the real
> time project on unix based platforms .
>

The code you refer to is a sample load test case and 12 seconds was
merely an example.


> 2) LoadTest
> -------------
>
> Please have a look on result.xml which i have attached .I have
> redirected the output
> of junit to xml file .My question is
> 1) For the first time ,it takes 0.12 sec .Later than it takes
> only 0.5,0.6 ,0.15 ,0 etc
> Is there any valid comments to "why time goes like this " .
> 2) For some times ,it shows no time .I dont know the reason .
>

The result.xml doesn't include the stated numbers, but I suspect the
numbers are varying based on the load and optimizations of your HTTP server.

Mike
